course.subject: PHYS
course.name: Mathematical Methods in Physics II
course.description: Physical applications of analytic and numerical methods are studied in such topics as differential equations, Fourier series, Laplace transforms, matrices and vectors.
course.prerequisites: MATH 2023 AND MATH 2121 AND (MATH 2352 OR PHYS 2124)

reviews.author: Wen Han
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers the following topics:
Taylor Series
Complex Numbers
Complex Analysis (Contour Integrals, Laurent Series and Argument Principle)
Fourier Series and Transform
Bessel Functions and Legendre Polynomials
[Homogeneous] Partial Differential Equations
Special Functions

The course mainly teaches you how to you use these mathematical tools. While it is sufficient for UG level physics, you don't learn too much in this course. If you wish to go more in depth, I would suggest taking PHYS 5110.
reviews.comment_teaching: While Professor Yang has a bit of a monotonic voice and teaches at a fairly slow pace (which makes you want to sleep), he sometimes bring up some fairly interesting stories to keep you attentive. His slow pacing will allow most students to keep up with minimal  effort.
reviews.comment_grading: The grade for this course is really good (mainly because of the small size). Out of the 25 students, there are about 4 A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
The weekly assignments are just questions from the textbook (Mathematical Methods in the Physical Sciences). All of the questions are extremely straightforward and can be solved using Mathematica if you are stuck.

You are allowed to bring in a single double-sided A4 cheat sheet for the exams. While the exams are within the syllabus, the questions will be out of the scope of the textbook. If you wish to do well in the exams, I would suggest looking at other textbooks.
